conclusion: Two metal rails are placed parallel on a horizontal plane, separated by 0.6 m, connected to lamps L1 and L2 with specifications '3V, 3W' and '6V, 6W'. A conductor rod with resistance 1 Ω is placed on the rails, perpendicular to them, with a magnetic field of 1 T passing vertically.

The image shows two parallel metal rails with a conductor rod ab placed perpendicular to them. A magnetic field B = 1 T passes vertically through the plane. The left end of the rails is connected to lamp L1 (3V, 3W) and the right end to lamp L2 (6V, 6W).
The conductor rod ab is moving to the right at a constant speed under the action of an external force.
The magnetic field B = 1 T induces an electromotive force (EMF) in the conductor rod due to the motion.
The EMF induced in the conductor rod causes a current to flow from L1 to L2 through the rod.
When the rod moves, the current i is given by the equation i = vB/r, where v is the velocity of the rod, B is the magnetic field, and r is the resistance of the rod.
Given that the rod's resistance r = 1 Ω and assuming v = 1 m/s for calculation purposes, the induced current i = 1 A.
The power P1 at lamp L1 is calculated using the voltage V1 and current i: P1 = V1 * i = 3 V * 1 A = 3 W.
Since lamp L1 just lights up normally, the power P1 is equal to the power P2 at lamp L2, i.e., P2 = 3 W.
